newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli budget not seen lifting economy in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Israeli budget not seen lifting economy in 1997.

text.p: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu won a bruising battle with parliament to cut this year's budget, but economists, investors and business executives are not convinced it can revive the flagging economy.

Parliament Wednesday approved a budget for 1997 of just under 190 billion shekels ($58.5 billion), including about 7 billion shekels ($2.15 billion) in spending cuts, higher taxes and higher fees. The Treasury said cuts made up about 4.7 billion shekels ($1.45 billion) of the total.
Analysts and business executives said they were disappointed with the extent of tax rises and other revenue-raising measures, which took the place of genuine budget cuts.

"I see this budget more like a muddling through. There's no real message of reform, such as closing redundant offices. It's all general budget cutting," said Jonathan Katz, chief economist for Solid Finance Markets.

"In my opinion the mix of higher taxes and lower spending cuts didn't help -- it was not as good as expected -- but the reductions are still big," said Gidi Halpern of Meitav Investments and Securities. "The people we're in touch with in the Treasury are very optimistic."
The budget met strong opposition in Parliament, which led the Treasury to back down on plans to cut child allowances and impose fees for doctors' visits.
Instead, taxes on gasoline and cigarettes were raised, and income tax brackets will not be adjusted for inflation, which will effectively raise tax rates.

Analysts doubt that higher taxes will hurt Netanyahu politicially. But, they say, if he fails to deliver on his vows to undertake wide-ranging privatisation and liberalisation measures, confidence in his economic policy will suffer.

"Other than rhetoric, we've seen very little," said Katz. "If by the end of the first quarter, we don't see big sales of government companies, people will assume you can't count on them to do anything."
For now, however, the big question for Israeli business is whether the cuts will be enough to move the Bank of Israel to lower short-term interest rates and bring about a depreciation of the shekel.

In Israel's export-driven economy, a depreciation is widely seen as the means of sparking economic growth. Gross domestic product growth slowed to an estimated 4.4 percent in 1996 and is expected to slow to 4 percent this year.
But analysts were divided about whether a real interest rate cut is in the works.

"With this budget it is hard to see a reduction of interest rates and without that the exchange rate situation will not improve," said Michael Strauss, chairman of Strauss Dairies, one of Israel's biggest food companies.
